1731.36.text: We're going to wait and see, first, whether they get their permission and see how bad it is

1736.68.text: But I think we will need a place as a bolthole just to run to when we can't take it any longer

1745.36.text: Annabel has reached the end of her tether with basement digs

1749.02.text: - her street is one of the most developed in the borough

1752.08.text: Half the houses are being done up,

1754.04.text: most with basements, doubling their value from five to ten million pounds.

1761.08.text: Annabel and her husband Stanley have lived here for twenty three years,

1765.66.text: and for the past eight been hemmed in by building work.

1770.66.text: I mean we've tried to stop all these developments,

1774.90.text: and all to no, to no avail, I mean the local planning officer gets these letters

1783.62.text: And they allow these permissions for one floor, two floors below

1787.96.text: and we have this nightmare on our hands - you can hear now!

1791.18.text: This goes on all the time.

1793.22.text: All along the road, out of twelve houses we've got six of them at it.

1800.18.text: and it's practically every other one,

1802.04.text:
so everyone in the whole terrace has got a
naughty neighbour.

1809.82.text: Well, the first fifteen years that we lived here we never had any problem from any sort of neighbour,

1815.01.text: they were all lovely and they were all friends - and now that has all gone.

1820.60.text: Is it like being at the dentist?

1824.26.text: It is actually, yes, it is like being at the dentist!

1832.34.text: With two more of her neighbours waiting to hear if the council will green-light their basement builds

1837.98.text: Annabel is heading to a local estate agent to hatch an escape plan

1843.06.text: Perhaps we may have to think of getting a place to use as a bolthole.

1848.88.text: I'm not interested in anything so-called modern.

1851.84.text: Super, understood, and how many bedrooms do you need, Annabel?

1857.18.text: And, of course, I'm not very happy about the idea of selling it to the enemy.

1861.14.text: As you know within the Royal borough at the moment there are so many planning applications

1864.66.text: which they're currently stalled up, er, at the Royal borough of Kensington and Chelsea planning department

1868.82.text: and working out whether or not they going to approve or, or decline; but I think there are very few

1873.94.text: streets left in Kensington and Chelsea where you won't have some form of building work going on.

1878.66.text: That gives us a huge difficulty of where do we go to

1885.24.text:
It's four weeks since Kensington Council
declared a moratorium on mega basement applications.

1895.02.text: We're now joined by Conservative Councillor Tim Coleridge, cabinet member for planning policy for Kensington and Chelsea

1901.64.text: Now, we do have an issue with space in London - what's the problem with building downwards?

1905.38.text: It is extremely trying for our residents when street after street

1908.66.text: sometimes have two or three basements being dug at the same time

1911.92.text: and that's increased like tenfold in the last eleven, twelve...

1914.07.text: It looks as if digging double basements - known as icebergs - may be banned completely

1919.04.text: if the council can get government approval.

1923.00.text: And I suspect that every council in London will be looking to see whether we get this,

1926.68.text: and they will almost certainly follow suit

1932.78.text: Westminster is a neighbouring borough that's paying close attention

1936.70.text: because here in Belgravia a basement bill went so badly wrong

1941.40.text: that it's become the stuff of local legend.

1951.98.text: You know, the house is, er, is what I would describe as the benchmark case for disasters with property development in London.

1961.38.text: And you mention Chester Row and the taxi driver will throw back his head and laugh

1964.96.text: and he'll say 'Oh! That's that house there with the Skip in the road!'

1970.03.text: And then I'll go 'Yeah, that's us'

1972.90.text: Well, this is a Christmas card that we did the first Christmas it happened

1978.64.text: The Evening Standard printed it on their Christmas Eve front cover.

1991.06.text: Four years on the Hugh-Williams still have a quarter of a million pound repair bill

1997.44.text: Plus their memories of an eventful night with a sunken skip

2003.20.text: Well, um, it was actually in the morning - it was around about five o'clock in the morning

2008.46.text: and I had been asleep and I'd been with our housekeeper Leanne and my family were away at our, erm, country house

2017.54.text: and she came and woke me up

2020.76.text: That's extraordinary. What had happened to it?

2023.14.text: The skip had fallen and sunk into the street.

2027.44.text: The soil had been there for a substantial amount of time and when it rained it became a lot heavier

2034.18.text: and the road where they'd been doing a double basement underneath

2037.10.text: - they were building a cinema or something - it had fallen in through the road

2042.46.text: and had destroyed all the piping so water was going through their house and into our house

2049.92.text: erm, and destroyed the bottom and all the foundations of our house

2053.82.text: and we were just asked to come out, and lucky we didn't have the dogs here otherwise they probably would have drowned!

2060.78.text: This is a video of it after the skip had been removed.

2068.00.text: Yah, it's a lot of water!

2072.08.text:
Lucas then Michael called in a structural
engineer to look at the damage.

2077.54.text: He didn't like coming in this room. I mean, he just basically said I don't want to be in this room

2081.90.text: until we get some Acrow props; once the Acrow props are in it's perfectly alright to be in here

2088.36.text: We realised that the party wall act was completely insufficient and therefore we would have to try to sue the people next door

2093.46.text: - just to put our house back in order

2097.30.text:
The property was owned by a company in
an offshore tax haven

2101.86.text: Both it and the basement subcontractor have since closed down.

2106.74.text: Then we had absolutely nobody to go against for restitution or rebuilding costs

2111.64.text: I mean, forget it: there was just absolutely nobody there.

2115.22.text: You do sound angry, I have to say

2118.16.text: Of course I'm angry underneath it. I, I think it's disgusting

2122.16.text: I don't really want anybody to feel sorry for me, but I do want people to learn from this process

2127.38.text: and realise that actually when people do this kind of thing it's completely irresponsible

2131.76.text: - the law is absolutely insufficient to protect homeowners

2141.00.text: Back in Kensington and Chelsea the dig next door to Jeremy has been going on for 15 months

2149.68.text: and the reality of living day to day so close to one of the biggest excavations in the borough

2158.64.text: You never stick to your area - you have another frontage the other side and you have it this side

2163.10.text: Okay? So you just stop doing it!

2165.66.text: If you're reasonable, unreasonable, but when you overstep the mark the answer is not

2170.40.text: 'the work is here, it has to be done'

2173.00.text: Not at my expense and inconvenience - there's a middle ground

2176.64.text: Well,  I think it's, it's perfectly, I'm perfectly within my rights to say

2179.92.text: 'Listen guys, you have your area, it's a double frontage'

2182.94.text: 'If you want to use that double frontage, fine'

2185.62.text: 'But at the end of the day you don't come across mine; and if you want to come across mine then you ask to do so'

2192.68.text: Another thorn in Jeremy's side is the army of grab lorries servicing the dig.

2198.42.text: We've seen examples where these things have been here for nearly an hour at a time

2203.00.text: On average, you know, we've had our road blocked for three and half to four hours a day

2222.86.text: You can see - it can't get round - it's totally impractical for this road

2228.09.text: It's been passed by the council - it's totally impractical; they won't be able to get through here

2231.78.text: because there are two transits - they're gonna back it up

2236.48.text: so, we'll just start the process we normally start

2243.74.text: There is no way they'll be able to get through that - I mean it's almost like going for your driving test

2248.88.text: and doing a three-point turn all over again

2264.36.text: Oh, he's obviously a more skillful driver than I thought

2267.82.text: Do they always manage to get through?

2269.38.text: No, it's, erm I would say it's probably a 50% chance

2276.90.text: Although the council are investigating Jeremy's catalogue of complaints,

2280.74.text: they're just not moving fast enough for him.

2284.56.text: I can't believe that, er, the council authorities will not attend to this for the

2291.04.text: remaining duration of the build - it's not as if it's three months; it's over a year!

2296.26.text: We pay taxes and we pay these council officers' salaries

2301.34.text: so why should they not be accountable to us?

2304.04.text: And I'm worried that you're getting overwrought

2307.42.text: I wouldn't go, I wouldn't, I wouldn't necessarily say that it's stressing me out but the fact is

2313.34.text: it's, it's complications you could do without; these things could be sorted out and should be sorted out

2320.10.text: I don't understand why they take so much time

2322.08.text: I don't understand why they're so problematic, erm, is there an agenda here?

2336.18.text:
Away from the bitter battles in central
London and pushed along by rising property prices,

2348.44.text: Do I look, do I look as if, I've got, brushed me hair?

2352.00.text: So, how long have you lived here, John?

2356.64.text: And how's , how's the neighbourhood changed?

2362.60.text: People that've moved in, judges and doctors and lawyers and all that

2368.74.text: These house have gone from, within the time that I've lived here, from 30,000 to one and a half million

2374.80.text: I mean that's kind of a bit freaky.

2377.64.text: where East End was always classed as slum area

2380.00.text: and now suddenly everybody wants to be in the East End

2384.76.text: What's it like, having all these basements dug nearby?

2387.72.text: Doesn't really worry us at all - I don't worry about things like that

2392.92.text: but as local basement builder Roger knows only too well, not everyone is eager to

2400.36.text: I've observed the, what's happening up there - there's a couple of basements that have been going on for about a year, I should think

2406.60.text: Well, that's because there's, like, five in a row so we've gone from one to the next one..

2415.08.text: People who are having it done or are thinking of having it done are absolutely fine

2420.76.text: but the people who've got no intention of having it done

2423.82.text: are obviously not keen on it in any way, shape or form.

2429.28.text: Roger's been in the basement building game for six years

2432.76.text: The starting price of one of his digs is a hundred and sixty thousand pounds

2437.58.text: We started off doing one and then the neighbours saw it and it just kind of snowballed from there.

2443.56.text: How long have you been working on this street then?

2446.12.text: Been working on this street for well over a year now

2448.82.text: and I think it's going to be for a few more years to come as well.

2452.98.text: Hopefully I'm not becoming a hate figure.

2455.24.text: Trouble is, as it's classed as major structural engineering works

2458.68.text: you can't make an omelette without smashing a few eggs

2464.38.text: One of his current clients is Jo. For her and her husband digging a basement

2469.76.text: is about keeping a home in London for themselves and their two children

2475.86.text: We've outgrown the house; tried buying locally

2479.38.text: - it's just there - our offer was not even responded to

2483.07.text: so this was our option for staying in London

2486.02.text: You know, past 14, I don't think our kids would ever forgive us had we left London

2491.54.text: but we've got this next eight years of kind of kid madness to get through

2498.28.text: and it's how we do it without us going mad.

2501.86.text: So their solution is to spend two hundred and ten thousand pounds

2506.26.text: but Jo won't be adding a wine cellar or a swimming pool

2509.44.text: - just some vital living space below stairs.

2512.46.text: This whole kitchen area will start at this wall and go to the end of the conservatory

2518.64.text: and that will be the footbridge to the family room downstairs.

2521.78.text: Ron, next door, who is an eighty seven-year-old ex-Flamenco dancer

2529.88.text: This area there'll be a bathroom area and a walk-in wardrobe.

2534.94.text: Our other neighbors on the other side, that live in a council property,

2537.54.text: They're fine about it - they've been really helpful

2541.02.text: This footprint will be a bedroom - master bedroom.

2544.60.text: It would be odd for it suddenly to meet resistance, you know, because everyone is, 'Oh, yeah, we understand,

2550.86.text: the houses are quite [GESTURES CRAMPED] you know, and everyone's struggling to fit in with kids.

2558.76.text: Roger's dug 50 basements this year and he's on target to triple that next year to 150.

2568.94.text: We've just completed a basement for a guy who's a forklift driver

2572.36.text: and lived in London all his life and scraped the money together and remortgaged his house

2579.28.text: and we've just completed his basement.

2582.60.text: In the country people just wouldn't consider digging a basement -

2586.68.text: down and around there you just put your house on the market and buy a bigger one.

2593.92.text: Back in Kensington and Chelsea it's the moment of truth for the Council.

2599.40.text: After two months consideration, the government's Planning Inspectorate

2605.76.text: BBC London 94.9 - It's 07:47 and Kensington and Chelsea has become the first council

2611.32.text: in the whole country to restrict basement development.

2614.28.text: The message is that the borough really does mean business now - it is a historic moment, I think.

2620.78.text: For the media, who have been reporting on the basement saga,

2626.40.text: It's a huge story for us.

2628.08.text: I mean, Kensington & Chelsea have been fighting a legal battle with the, the developers and the construction companies

2633.98.text: for a couple of years now and, in fact, taken them to the Planning Inspectorate

2637.66.text: which ruled in favor of the council

2641.16.text: The decision means that, in the Borough of Kensington and Chelsea,

2645.06.text: you can only build a single-story basement.

2648.14.text:
So today I'm off to see Tim Coleridge,
head of planning at, er,  Kensington & Chelsea council

2653.94.text:
What I really object to is when they build
underground rooms

2656.80.text: - they say they're going to be like children's playrooms, underground sitting rooms,

2660.78.text: but then they actually put their staff in there with no daylight.

2663.24.text: So I want to talk to him a little bit about their new policy

2667.34.text: and, er, what it might mean for the borough

2670.34.text: Er, um, there was an application which was granted some years ago, uh,

2673.82.text: where the owner, erm, loved diving off a very high diving board,

2677.66.text: so he built a swimming pool in, er, Notting Hill Gate

2680.72.text: which is, um, high enough to dive off a 20 foot board, um, into his very deep swimming pool.

2687.14.text: But you might put off Billionaires from living here 'cos they might think 'Right, we'll go to Marylebone instead.'

2691.66.text: They're very welcome to do so.

2699.05.text: It's not going to stop people applying and building modest one-story basements

2702.75.text: which will have their own difficulties,

2705.17.text: but they'll have to make their choice, won't they?

2706.90.text: Do they want the want single storey basement to be the swimming pool or do they want the single storey basement to be the wine cellar?

2713.62.text: What a tough choice to make, you know?

2714.88.text: So that's the end of the iceberg home as we've known and loved it, I mean, what are we going to write about?

2719.78.text: What are you going to do, then? Are you going to cut that up all into little bits?

2722.52.text: Get it down to three seconds!

2726.18.text: I thought that was very interesting, um, I, I still feel, however, that

2731.60.text: um, even the single storey basements, er, are going to carry on in large numbers so I don't

2737.08.text:
think it's the end of basement hell for
central London by any means.

2747.54.text: and so the divisive iceberg home has run aground in Kensington.

2752.70.text: There will be no more double or triple basements built here,

2759.02.text:
but for basement digs already on the go, and for
developers, builders and neighbors caught up in them -

2765.40.text: the journey is far from over

2769.12.text: The Royal Borough of Kensington magazine - I saved it for you

2778.54.text: but they're still allowing one floor down

2782.70.text: Well, it's a good thing that it's not three floors, but one floor's bad enough...

2801.26.text: The answer is not, erm, in my view, what, one, where one should just walk away from it and allow developers,

2809.14.text: who are making massive profit margins at the expense of the common man,

2814.18.text: to just get away with this without any accountability whatsoever.
